The @January6thCmte returned today for its third public hearing.

We heard testimony from the then-vice president’s close aides and legal experts – Each hearing, we learn more about the events that led up to the deadly attack and those responsible. https://t.co/DyUnHazWMe

Biofuels are a win-win-win solution to addressing high gas prices.

https://t.co/XW4E24lPty

At the grocery store and at the gas pump, families are feeling the effects of inflation every single day.

Sending my deepest condolences to the entire Casten family during this difficult time. I'm so sorry for your loss.

When I read about this case in 2017, I knew something had to change - 68k women were silenced by arbitration clauses.

It inspired me to pass a bill to end forced arbitration for sexual assault & harassment, so future survivors can have their day in court.https://t.co/WyUWbnWHLC

While yesterday was #FlagDay, every day we should honor our nation's symbol of liberty, justice and the veterans who fought to protect those values.

For more than 100 years, Caterpillar has called Illinois home. The decision to relocate its headquarters to Texas is incredibly disappointing.

Despite this move, CAT has pledged to preserve and grow jobs in downstate Illinois. You can bet I'll hold them to it.

Healthcare workers courageously provide sexual and reproductive healthcare in the face of unrelenting threats, violence and harassment. 

That’s why I’m proud to cosponsor the #HealthcareProvidersSafetyAct to ensure providers get the security they need and deserve. https://t.co/5ScWd6Qhh6

#OnThisDay 247 years ago, the @USArmy was created.

Today we celebrate them and their loved ones - To the generations of brave Americans who have served the United States in an Army uniform, past and present: thank you.

This morning, the @January6thCmte held its second public hearing examining the dangerous actions that laid the groundwork for the deadly attack on the U.S. Capitol.

As we continue uncovering the truth of January 6th, I encourage everyone to tune in to these historic hearings.

After being knocked unconscious, Officer Caroline Edwards returned to the front lines of the attack on our Capitol to protect us and defend democracy

Thank you for putting your life on the line, and for the sacrifice you and your colleagues made to keep our nation secure.

Tonight, I will be attending the @January6thCmte’s first public hearing. 

With this hearing, a moment of reckoning begins in our nation. This bipartisan committee’s work is critical to protecting our democracy and the fabric of our nation.

From Uvalde to Buffalo, Sandy Hook to Columbine, our children's lives continue to be robbed by gun violence. 
 
This evening, I joined my colleagues in the House to pass a package of common sense bills to help us put a stop to these tragedies. https://t.co/NHXeiMrDnt

The gun violence epidemic in America will only get worse if we don't act now.

Today, the House is voting on the #ProtectingOurKidsAct, which will help reduce gun violence in our communities and save countless lives. https://t.co/69NkKaDDmv

#OnThisDay in 1944, Allied forces landed on the beaches of Normandy to fight for freedom and democracy.

Today, @RepCindyAxne and I sent a letter urging @CommerceGov to prioritize rural communities when federal funds are available through our bipartisan innovation legislation. 

By investing in rural America, we can boost American competitiveness while creating more jobs at home.
Congratulations to @KnoxCollege1837 graduates! May your graduation be the beginning of many more wonderful achievements in your life.

As a proud member of the Rural Broadband Task Force, I've been working hard to make sure Illinoisans have access to broadband internet — especially in our rural communities.

I'm thrilled that this expansion will create 25,000 NEW jobs in the state & boost current workers' wages!

Below is my statement on the historic @EPA biofuel announcement ⬇️ https://t.co/j81PgJzq24

This rhetoric is beyond absurd - it's dangerous. Claiming members of the media are "terrorists" for calling out lies is beyond shameful. 

And, as a former journalist, I would suggest they might want to consider grammar lessons, too.

This morning, @SenatorDurbin, @SenDuckworth, and I sent a letter to @TheJusticeDept urging an investigation into reports of violence and abuse at USP Thomson.

These allegations are deeply alarming and need to be addressed immediately.

Pride Month also reminds us of the trailblazers who fought for decades to pave the way for equality. We must honor their work by getting the #EqualityAct to @POTUS's desk to protect the rights of LGBTQ+ Americans under law.

Today kicks off #PrideMonth - a time to celebrate our LGBTQ+ community and the progress we've made toward equality.

This month, and every month, we must remain committed to standing up against hate and intolerance - to ensure LGBTQ+ Americans can live safely and authentically. https://t.co/JHfm5nGGpB

Everyone should have access to high-speed internet. Period.

Thanks to @POTUS's new Affordable Connectivity Program, 1 in 4 American households can receive a discount on their monthly internet bill. To check if you're eligible, visit https://t.co/9YxSNo62rm. https://t.co/yTgTwTnHdb

One week ago, 19 children and two adults lost their lives in the worst elementary school shooting since Sandy Hook.

Gun violence is more than a statistic -- it's people's lives. As leaders, it's our responsibility to work together to end the violence.

On #MemorialDay, we honor service members from all walks of life who made the ultimate sacrifice for our country.

We are forever grateful for their courageous service. https://t.co/0z2YyMHJ99

Irma Garcia, 48

Irma has been described as a “second mom” to her nephew and her students, as well as having been a “sweet, kind, loving” wife and mother with the greatest personality. https://t.co/kTzUmyO9Zz

Eva Mireles, 44

Eva’s daughter has written that she is so happy that so many people “know what a hero looks like.” She loved to talk to their dogs in silly voices and sing karaoke. https://t.co/ZAkwtFivin

Layla Salazar, 10

Layla loved jamming to “Sweet Child O’ Mine” by Guns ‘N’ Roses with her dad on the way to school and was known as the “princess” in her family. https://t.co/Eiura4Nm3z

Maite Yuleana Rodriguez, 10

Maite’s family described her as a “sweet, smart little girl.” https://t.co/OknuI1Dg6K

Makenna Lee Elrod, 10

Makenna’s aunt wrote that she “had the biggest heart and loved her family and friends so much” and that her "smile would light up the room.” https://t.co/7lWHfllHJ8

Rojelio Torres, 10

Rojelio’s aunt said he was a very intelligent, hard-working and helpful boy. https://t.co/CUC1j8ZS9N

Alithia Ramirez, 10

Alithia’s father said, “she loved to draw” and wanted to be an artist. She had recently entered a drawing into the Doodle for Google contest. https://t.co/SGdWn8c0GD

Eliahana Cruz Torres, 10

Eliahana was looking forward to her final softball game of the season that was scheduled for the day of the shooting, she wanted to make the All-Stars team. https://t.co/yATawVgnzn

Miranda Mathis, 11 

Miranda’s friend, Anairayah’s mother said Miranda, “was very loving and very talkative.” She always asked her to do her hair like Anairayah’s. https://t.co/DyaA5sFVmu

Jailah Nicole Silguero, 10

Jailah loved to dance and film TikTok videos. Jailah and Jayce were cousins. https://t.co/6TsWvOt73Y

Jayce Luevanos, 10

Jayce’s grandparents said he was a happy and loved boy. He would make them coffee every morning and write them notes saying “I love you, Grandpa.” He died along with his cousin, Jaliah Nicole Silguero. https://t.co/RmKxohV7F8

Nevaeh Alyssa Bravo, 10 

Nevaeh’s cousin said she would put a smile on everyone’s face. https://t.co/qwCu1VJIhd

Tess Marie Mata, 10 

Tess’ sister said she loved TikTok dances, Ariana Grande and the Houston Astros. She was saving money to take her family to Disney World. https://t.co/voF0nn8oPA

Jacklyn Cazares, 9

Jacklyn’s father said she was “full of life and love.” She recently sent off her older sister to prom. https://t.co/kaR0aPZaC8

Annabell Guadalupe Rodríguez, 10 

Annabell was a third grader at the school. She was in the same classroom as her cousin, Jackie Cazares, who was also shot and killed. Her sister wrote that the two are “dancing up in the sky, watching over us.” https://t.co/86Off1UjWh

Xavier Lopez, 10 

Xavier was counting down the days until he could attend Flores Middle School in Uvalde. His mother said she will never forget his smile, “It would always cheer anyone up.” https://t.co/IKRyNYH08n

Uziyah Garcia, 9 

Uziyah leaves behind two sisters. His uncle described him as a “great kid, full of life; he loved anything with wheels and video games.” https://t.co/tH0r2iTvx3

José Flores Jr., 10 

José loved baseball and video games. His father described him as always being full of energy; he was a wonderful big brother to his two siblings. https://t.co/EZ0PqYkZgV

Amerie Jo Garza just celebrated her 10th birthday two weeks ago.

Amerie was described as “super-outgoing” and a “teacher’s pet” by her grandmother Berlinda Irene Arreola; she loved nothing more than her family. https://t.co/mB6cwp1itz

Ellie Garcia, 9 

Ellie played on the city’s youth basketball team, and her father, Steven, said she was “a doll and the happiest ever.” She dreamed of wearing a purple dress to her quinceañera and becoming a teacher. https://t.co/jb6hBJWTmV

Alexandria Aniyah Rubio, 10 

Alexandria had just earned a spot on the All-A honor roll and good citizen award; her relatives described her as a “bright light in everyone’s life.” She loved playing softball. https://t.co/q6PHLBtyQI

On Tuesday, the bright futures of 19 students and two teachers at Robb Elementary School were tragically cut short. 

Let’s honor the lives lost by this senseless act of violence.🧵

I’m a mother who raised three boys - today’s tragic news makes me sick to my stomach. My heart breaks for the children and families of Robb Elementary School. 

These innocent lives have been taken too soon. It’s time for Congress to take action. https://t.co/wgmj9wHG8D

Today, I cast my early vote in the 2022 Illinois Primary Election.

No American should feel afraid to go grocery shopping, go to school or practice their religion because of domestic terrorists. 

This evening, I voted to provide law enforcement agencies with the tools and resources to combat these threats and keep Americans safe.

The racially-motivated shooting in Buffalo was a senseless act of hatred and on the same day multiple shootings occurred across Milwaukee.

Today, we mark one million American lives lost to COVID-19. 

My heart goes out to everyone who has lost a loved one to this deadly virus. Let this grim milestone be a reminder to get vaccinated, stay up to date on your booster shots and do your part to keep COVID-19 at bay.

As Russia continues to wage war on the people of Ukraine, we must do our part to defend innocent lives and democracy.

This week, my bill passed the House floor with 113 Republicans voting for the bill. With this bipartisan support, Leader @SenSchumer and @SenatorDurbin got the bill on the Senate floor today where it passed UNANIMOUSLY!

I reintroduced the bill in the 116th and 117th Congress, and in 2021, it finally received a hearing in @JudiciaryDems and @HouseJudiciary! During these hearings, victims testified about their experiences with forced arbitration and workplace sexual assault and harassment.

As we worked to rally support for the bill, 56 Attorneys General from all 50 states, territories and D.C. called for its passage in 2018. 

Soon, tech giants, like Microsoft and Uber, took action and removed forced arbitration clauses buried in their employment documents.

I knew right away that we needed to put a stop to this insidious practice. After working with my team to craft legislation, we first introduced the Ending Forced Arbitration of Sexual Harassment Act in December 2017!

In 2017, I read a @washingtonpost story about the culture of sexual assault & harassment at Sterling, Inc. and how victims were barred from seeking justice in court due to forced arbitration agreements hidden in their employment paperwork.

https://t.co/zZL7SwB7CH

The Capitol was stormed and our democracy — the foundation of America — was threatened.

“Get your gas masks out.”

That’s what I heard as an angry mob crashed through the House Floor’s glass windows.

It was Jan 6 and I was at the Capitol working to certify the 2020 election results — my constitutional duty. The violence forced us to pause our work.

"This is what we do: We stay and report."
 
Journalists document our history and those at the Capitol on January 6th risked their lives to do so. I was proud to thank them & all our news staff with a resolution recognizing their bravery and service to the truth that day.

Nothing is more important to our nation than protecting our democracy, so every American can have their voice heard.

When even one small business closes, an entire community loses.

I applaud Max, and @GalenaCanningCo, for their hard work and determination in the face of such a big loss. 

I know your dad would be so proud of you, Max!

Stories like the one Max and his family told me demonstrate why our small businesses need the right tools and resources to prepare for their future. 

That’s why I introduced the Small Business Succession Planning Act, to provide small business owners with the support they need.

Sadly, Max lost his father, who owned the company, roughly one year ago – just before the pandemic hit.

When his father died, the company didn't have a succession plan in place and Max had to move back home to take over the family business.
